sp.l: Thou art all virtue.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I'll tell thee how: Baldwin the emperor,
Pretending title, more through tyranny,
Then right of conquest, or descent, usurped
The style of lord o'er all the Grecian islands,
And under colour of an amity
With Crete, preferred the marquess mountferato
To be our governor; the Cretians vexed
By the ambitious Turks, in hope of aid
From the emperor, received for general,
This mountferato; he (The wars appeased)
Plots with the state of Venice, and takes money
Of them for Candy: they paid well, he steals
Away in secret; since which time, that right
The state of Venice claims o'er Candy, is
By purchase, not inheritance, or conquest:
And hence grows all our quarrel.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: So a usurer
Or Lumbard-jew, might with some bags of trash,
Buy half the western world.

sp.speaker: Cas
sp.l: Money Arcanes
Is now a god on earth: it cracks virginities,
And turns a christian, Turk;
Bribes justice, cutthroats honour, does what not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Not captives Candy.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Nor makes thee dishonest,
Nor me a coward — now sir, here is homely,
But friendly entertainment.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sir, I find it.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: And like it, do ye not?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My repair speaks for me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Fernando we were speaking off — how this?
sp.stage: Enter Gonzalo, and Gaspero, with a casket.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Your friend, and servant.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Creditors, my lord,
Are masters and no servants: as the world goes,
Debtors are very slaves to those to whom
They have been beholding to; in which respect,
I should fear you Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Me my lord?
You owe me nothing.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: What nor love, nor money?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Yes, love, I hope not money.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: All this bravery,
Will scarcely make that good.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: 'Tis done already:
See sir, your mortgage which I only took,
In case you and your son had in the wars
Miscarried: I yield it up again: 'tis yours.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Are ye so conscionable?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: 'Tis your own.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Pish, pish, I'll not receive what is not mine,
That were a dangerous business.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Sir, I am paid for't,
The sums you borrowed, are returned; the bonds
Cancelled, and your acquittance formerly sealed:
Look here sir, Gaspero is witness to it.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: My honoured lord, I am.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: My lord Fernando,
Arcanes and the rest, you all shall testify,
That I acquit lord Cassilane for ever,
Of any debts to me.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: 'Tis plain and ample:
Fortune will once again smile on us fairly.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: But hark ye, hark ye, if you be in earnest,
Whence comes this bounty? or whose is't?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: In short,
The great Erota, by this secretary,
Returned me my full due.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Erota? why
Should she do this?

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: You must ask her the cause,
She knows it best.

sp.speaker: Cas
sp.l: So ho; Arcanes, none
But women pity us? soft-hearted women,
I am become a brave fellow now, Arcanes,
Am I not?

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Why sir, if the gracious Princess
Have taken more special notice of your services,
And means to be more thankful than some others,
It were an injury to gratitude,
To disesteem her favours.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: Sir she ever
For your sake most respectively loved me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The senate, and the body of this kingdom,
Are herein (Let me speak it without arrogance)
Beholding to her: I will thank her for it;
And if she have reserved a means whereby
I may repay this bounty with some service,
She shall be then my patroness: come sirs,
We'll taste a cup of wine together now.

sp.speaker: Gonz, Fernando,
sp.l: I must speak with you in secret.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall — now Gaspero, all's well.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: There's news
You must be acquainted with.
Come, there is no masterpiece in art, like policy. Ex.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: T the senate is informed at full.

sp.speaker: Mi.
sp.l: Gonzalo.
Dreams not of my arrival yet.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Nor thinks
'Tis possible his plots can be discovered:
He fats himself with hopes of crowns, and kingdoms,
And laughs securely, to imagine how
He means to gull all but himself: when truly,
None is so grossly gulled as he.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: There was never
A more arch villain.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Peace, the senate comes.
sp.stage: Enter Porphino pos. Senators, and Gaspero, attend.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: How closely, treason cloaks itself in forms
Of civil honesty?

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: And yet how palpably
Does heaven reveal it?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Gracious lords.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: The ambassador,
Lord Paulo Michael, advocate
To the great Duke of Venice.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You are most welcome,
Your master is a just and noble prince.

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: My lords, he bade me say; that you may know
How much he scorns, and (As good princes ought)
Defies base indirect, and godless treacheries;
To your more sacred wisdoms he refers
The punishment due to the false Gonzalo,
Or else to send him home to Venice.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Herein
The Duke is royal: Gaspero the prince
Of Cyprus answered he would come.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: My lords,
He will not long be absentEnter Philander, and Melitus.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: You Fernando,
Have made the state your debtor: worthy prince,
We shall be suitors to you for your presence,
In hearing, and determining of matters
Greatly concerning Candy.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Fathers, I am
A stranger.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Why, the cause (My lord) concerns
A stranger: please you seat yourself.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Howe'er
Unfit, since you will have it so (My lords)
You shall command me.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: You my lord Fernando,
With the ambassador, withdraw a while.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: My lords, we shall. Ex.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Melitus, and the secretary,
Give notice to Gonzalo, that the senate
Requires his presence. Ex. Gas. and Mel.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: What concerns the business? Enter Cas. and Arca.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Thus noble prince —

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Let me alone, thou troublest me,
I will be heard.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: You know not what you do.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Forbear: who's he that is so rude? what's he that dares
To interrupt our counsels?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: One that has guarded,
Those purple robes from cankers worse than moths,
One that hath kept your fleeces on your backs,
That would have been snatched from you: but I see
'Tis better now to be a dog, a spaniel
In times of peace, then boast the bruised scars,
Purchased with loss of blood in noble wars:
My lords, I speak to you.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: Lord Cassilane,
We know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Yes, you are set
Upon a bench of justice; and a day
Will come (Hear this, and quake ye potent great ones)
When you yourselves shall stand before a judge,
Who in a pair of scales will weigh your actions,
Without abatement of one grain: as then
You would be found full weight, I charge ye fathers
Let me have justice now.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Lord Cassilane,
What strange distemperature provokes distrust
Of our impartiality? be sure
We'll flatter no man's injuries.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: 'Tis well;
You have a law (Lords) that without remorse
Dooms such as are beleaguered with the curse
Of foul ingratitude unto death.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: We have.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Then do me justice.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Madman, whether runnest thou?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Peace Decius, I am deaf.

sp.speaker: Hyp.
sp.l: Will you forget
Your greatness and your modesty?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Hyparcha leave, I will not hear,

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Lady; great, gentle, lady.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Prithee young man forbear to interrupt me,
Triumph not in thy fortunes; I will speak.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: More uproars yet; who are they that disturb us?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The viper's come; his fears have drawn him hither,
And now (My lords) be chronicled for ever,
And give me justice against this vile monster,
This bastard of my blood.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: 'Tis justice fathers,
I sue for too: and though I might command it,
(If you remember lords, whose child I was)
Yet I will humbly beg it; this old wretch
'Has forfeited his life to me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Tricks, tricks;
Complots, devices, 'twixt these pair of young-ones,
To blunt the edge of your well tempered swords,
Wherewith you strike offenders, (Lords) but I
Am not a baby to be feared with bugbears,
'Tis justice I require.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You speak too tenderly; and too much, like yourself
To mean a cruelty; which would make monstrous
Your sex: yet for the love's sake, which you once
Pleased to pretend, give my grieved father leave
To urge his own revenge; you have no cause
For yours: keep peace about ye.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Will you hear me?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Here's some strange novelty.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Sure we are mocked,
Speak one at once: say wherein hath your son
Transgressed the law?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O the gross mists of dulness;
Are you this kingdom's oracles, yet can be
So ignorant? first hear, and then consider,
That I begotten him, gave him birth and life,
And education, were I must confess,
But duties of a father: I did more;
I taught him how to manage arms, to dare
An enemy; to court both death and dangers;
Yet these were but additions to complete
A well accomplished soldier: I did more yet.
I made him chief commander in the field
Next to myself, and gave him the full prospect
Of honour, and preferment; trained him up
In all perfections of a martialist:
But he unmindful of his gratitude,
You know with what contempt of my deserts,
First kicked against mine honour, scorned all
My services; then got the palm of glory
Unto himself: yet not content with this,
He (Lastly) hath conspired my death, and sought
Means to engage me to this lady's debt,
Whose bounty, all my whole estate could never
Give satisfaction too: now honoured fathers,
For this cause only, if your law be law,
And you the ministers of justice; then
Think of this strange ingratitude in him.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Can this be so Antinous?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: 'Tis all true,
Nor hath my much wronged father limned my faults
In colours half so black, as in themselves,
My guilt hath dyed them: were there mercy left,
Yet mine own shame would be my executioner:
Lords, I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thou beliest Antinous,
Thine innocence: alas (My lords) he's desperate,
And talks he knows not what: you must not credit
His lunacy; I can myself disprove
This accusation: Cassilane, be yet
More merciful; I beg it.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Time, nor fate,
The world, or what is in it, shall not alter
My resolution; he shall die.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: The senate's
Prayers; or weeping lovers, shall not alter
My resolution: thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Why madam,
Are ye all marble?

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Leave your shifts Antinous,
What plead you to your father's accusation?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Most fully guilty.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: You have doomed yourself,
We cannot quit you now.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: A burdened conscience
Will never need a hangman: hadst thou dared
To have denied it, than this sword of mine
Should on thy head have proved thy tongue a liar.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Thy sword? wretched old man, thou hast lived too long
To carry peace or comfort to thy grave;
Thou art a man condemned: my lords this tyrant
Had perished but for me, I still supplied
His miserable wants; I sent his daughter
Money to buy him food; the bread he eat,
Was from my purse: when he (Vaingloriously)
To dive into the people's hearts, had pawned
His birthright, I redeemed it, sent it to him,
And for requital, only made my suit,
That he would please to new receive his son
Into his favour, for whose love I told him
I had been still so friendly: but then he
As void of gratitude, as all good nature,
Distracted like a mad man, posted hither
To pull this vengeance on himself, and us;
For why, (My lords) since by the law, all means
Is blotted out of your commission,
As this hard hearted father hath accused
Noble Antinous, his unblemished son,
So I accuse this father, and crave judgement.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: All this is but deceit, mere trifles forged
By combination to defeat the process
Of justice, I will have Antinous' life.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: Sir, what do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: I will have Cassilane's.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cunning and cruel lady, runs the stream
Of your affections this way? have you not
Conquest enough by treading on my grave?
Unless you send me thither in a shroud
Steeped in my father's blood? as you are woman,
As the protests of love you vowed were honest;
Be gentler to my father.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Cassilane,
Thou hast a heart of flint: let my entreats,
My tears, the sacrifice of griefs unfeigned,
Melt it: yet be a father to thy son,
Unmask thy long besotted judgement, see
A low obedience kneeling at the feet
Of nature: I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Pish you cousin
Your hopes: your plots are idle: I am resolute.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Antinous, urge no further.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hence thou sorcery
Of a beguiling softness, I will stand,
Like the earth's centre, unmoved; lords your breath
Must finish these divisions: I confess
Civility doth teach I should not speak
Against a lady of her birth, so high
As great Erota, but her injuries
And thankless wrongs to me, urge me to cry
Aloud for justice, fathers.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Whether run you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: For (Honoured fathers) that you all may know
That I alone am not unmatchable
In crimes of this condition, lest perhaps
You might conceive, as yet the case appears,
That this foul stain, and guilt runs in a blood;
Before this presence, I accuse this lady
Of as much vile ingratitude to me.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Impudent traitor!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Her? O spare Antinous;
The world reputes thee valiant, do not soil
All thy past nobleness with such a cowardice,
As murdering innocent ladies will stamp on thee?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Brave prince, with what unwillingness I force
Her follies, and in those her sin, be witness,
All these about me: she is bloody minded.
And turns the justice of the law to rigor:
It is her cruelties, not I accuse her:
Shall I have audience?

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Let him speak my lords.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: Your memory will rot.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Cast all your eyes
On this, what shall I call her? truthless woman,
When often in my discontents, the sway
Of her unruly blood, her untamed passion,
(Or name it as you list) had hour by hour
Solicited my love, she vowed at last
She could not, would not live unless I granted
What she long sued for: I in tender pity,
To save a lady of her birth, from ruin
Gave her her life, and promised to be hers:
Nor urged I ought from her, but secrecy,
And then enjoined her to supply such wants
As I perceived my father's late engagements
Had made him subject to; what, shall I heap up
Long repetitions? she to quit my pity,
Not only hath discovered to my father
What she had promised to conceal, but also
Hath drawn my life into this fatal forfeit;
For which, since I must die, crave a like
Equality of justice against her;
Not that I covet blood, but that she may not
Practise this art of falsehood on some other,
Perhaps more worthy of her love hereafter.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.l: If this be true —

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: My lords, be as the law is,
Indifferent, upright, I do plead guilty:
Now sir, what glory have you got by this?
Alas man, I meant not to outlive thy doom;
Shall we be friends in death?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Hear me, the villain
Scandals her, honoured lords.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Leave off to dote,
And die a wise man ▪

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am overreached,
And mastered in my own resolution.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.l: Will ye be wilful madam? here's the curse
Of love's disdain.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Why sit you like dumb statues?
Demur no longer.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Cassilane, Erota,
Antinous, death ye ask; and 'tis your dooms,
You in your follies lived, die in your follies.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: I am revenged, and thank you for it.

sp.speaker: Er.
sp.l: Yes, and I: Antinous hath been gracious.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Sir, may I presume to crave a blessing from you
Before we part.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Yes, such a one as parents
Bestow on cursed sons now, now, I laugh
To see how those poor younglings are both cheated
Of life and comfort: look ye, look ye, lords,
I go but some ten minutes (More or less)
Before my time, but they have fiuely cozened
Themselves of many, many hopeful years
Amid their prime of youth and glory; nowEnter Annoph.
My vengeance is made full. Welcome my joy,
Thou com'st to take a seasonable blessing
From thy half buried father's hand; I am dead
Already girl, and so is she and he,
We all are wormsmeat now.

sp.speaker: Anno.
sp.l: I have heard all;
Nor shall you die alone: lords on my knees
I beg for justice too.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: 'Gainst whom, for what?

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: First let me be resolved; does the law favour
None, be they never so mighty?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Not the greatest.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Then justly I accuse of foul ingratitude
(My lords) you of the senate all, not one
Excepted.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Porp. us?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Annophill —

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: You are the authors
Of this unthrifty bloodshed; when your enemies
Came marching to your gates, your children sucked not
Safe at their mother's breasts, your very cloisters
Were not secure, your startingholes of refuge
Not free from danger, nor your lives your own:
In this most desperate ecstasy, my father,
This aged man, not only undertook
To guard your lives, but did so; and beat off
The daring foe; for you he pawned his lands,
To pay your soldiers, who without their pay
Refused to strike a blow: but (Lords) when peace
Was purchased for you, and victory brought home;
Where was your gratitude, who in your coffers
Hoarded the rusty treasure which was due
To my unminded father? he was glad
To live retired in want, in penury,
Whilst you made feasts of surfeit, and forgotten
Your debts to him: the sum of all is this,
You have been unthankful to him; and I crave
The rigor of the law against you all.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: My royal spirited daughter!

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.l: Annophill.
Thou art a worthy wench; let me embrace thee.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Lords, why do ye keep your seats? they are no places
For such as are offenders.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Though our ignorance
Of Cassilanes engagements might assuage
Severity of justice, yet to show
How no excuse should smooth a breach of law,
I yield me to the trial of it.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: So must I:
Great prince of Cyprus, you are left
The only moderator in this difference;
And as you are a prince be a protector
To woeful Candy.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: What a scene of misery
Hath thine obdurate frowardness (Old man)
Drawn on thy country's bosom? and for that
Thy proud ambition could not mount so high
As to be styled thy country's only patron,
Thy malice hath descended to the depth
Of hell, to be renowned in the title
Of the destroyer? dost thou yet perceive
What curses all posterity will brand
Thy grave with? that at once hast robbed this kingdom
Of honour and of safety.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: Children yet unborn
Will stop their ears when thou art named.

sp.speaker: Arc.
sp.l: The world will be too little to contain
The memory of this detested deed;
The furies will abhor it.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: What the sword
Could not enforce, your peevish thirst of honour
(A brave, cold, weak, imaginary fame)
Hath brought on Candy: Candy groans, not these
That are to die.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: 'Tis happiness enough
For them, that they shall not survive to see
The wounds wherewith thou stab'st the land that gave
Thee life and name.

sp.speaker: Dec.
sp.l: 'Tis Candy's wrack shall feel —

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: The mischief of your folly.

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Pos. Annophill —

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: I will not be entreated.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Prithee Annophill.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Why would ye urge me to a mercy which
You in yourself allow not?

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: 'Tis the law,
That if the party who complains, remit
The offender, he is freed: is't not so lords?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Pos. 'tis so.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Antinous, by my shame observe
What a close witchcraft popular applause is:
I am awaked, and with clear eyes behold
The lethargy wherein my reason long
Hath been becharmed: live, live, my matchless son,
Blessed in thy father's blessing; much more blessed
In thine own virtues: let me dew thy cheeks
With my unmanly tears: rise, I forgive thee:
And good Antinous, if I shall be thy father
Forgive me: I can speak no more.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Dear sir,
You new beget me now — madam your pardon,
I heartily remit you.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I as freely
Discharge thee Cassilane.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: My gracious lords,
Repute me not a blemish to my sex,
In that I strove to cure a desperate evil
With a more violent remedy: your lives,
Your honours are your own.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Then with consent
Be reconciled on all sides: please you fathers
To take your places.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Let us again ascend,
With joy and thankfulness to heaven: and now
To other business lords.

div.stage: Enter Gaspero, and Melitus, with Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Two hours and more sir,
The senate hath been set.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: And I not know it?
Who sits with them?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: My lord, the prince of Cyprus.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Gaspero,
Why how comes that to pass?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Some weighty cause
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Now lords the business? ha?
Who's here, Erota?

sp.speaker: Porp.
sp.l: Secretary do your charge
Upon that traitor.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Traitor?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Yes, Gonzalo, traitor,
Of treason to the peace and state of Candy,
I do arrest thee.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Me? thou dog?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: With licence
From this grave senate, I arrest thee likewise
Of treason to the state of Venice.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Ha?
Is Michael here? nay then I see
I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: I shall not be your Queen,
Your Duchess, or your empress.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: Dull, dull brain.
O I am fooled?

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Look sir, do you know this hand?

sp.speaker: Mic.
sp.l: Do you know this seal? First (Lords) he writes to Venice,
To make a perfect league, during which time
He would in private keep some troops in pay,
Bribe all the sentinels throughout this kingdom,
Corrupt the captains; at a banquet poison
The prince, and greatest peers, and in conclusion
Yield Candy slave to Venice.

sp.speaker: Gas.
sp.l: Next, he contracted
With the illustrious Princess, the lady Erota,
In hope of marriage with her, to deliver
All the Venetian gallantry, and strength,
Upon their first arrival, to the mercy
Of her and Candy.

sp.speaker: Erot.
sp.l: This is true Gonzalo.

sp.speaker: Gon.
sp.l: Let it be true: what then?

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: My lord ambassador,
What's your demand?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: As likes the state of Candy,
Either to sentence him as he deserves
Here, or to send him like a slave to Venice.

sp.speaker: Porph.
sp.l: We shall advise upon it.

sp.speaker: Gonz.
sp.l: O the devils,
That had not thrust this trick into my pate —
A politician fool? destruction, plague
Candy and Venice both.

sp.speaker: Pos.
sp.l: Porp. away with him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Come sir, I'll see you safe. Exeunt. Gonz. Mel.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Lords, ere you part
Be witness to another change of wonder;
Antinous, now be bold, before this presence,
Freely to speak, whether or no I used
The humblest means affection could contrive,
To gain thy love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Madam, I must confess it,
And ever am your servant.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Yes Antinous,
My servant, for my lord thou shalt be never:
I here disclaim the interest thou hadst once
In my too passionate thoughts. Most noble prince,
If yet a relic of thy wonted flames
Live warm within thy bosom, than I blush not
To offer up the assurance of my faith,
To thee that hast deserved it best.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: O madam,
You play with my calamity.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: Let heaven
Record my truth for ever.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: With more joy
Than I have words to utter, I accept it.
I also pawn you mine.

sp.speaker: Ero.
sp.l: The man that in requital
Of noble and unsought affection
Grows cruel, never loved, nor did Antinous.
Yet herein (Prince) ye are beholding to him;
For his neglect of me humbled a pride,
Which to a virtuous wife had been a monster.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: For which I'll rank him my deserving friend.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Much comfort dwell with you, as I could wish
To him I honour most.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: O my Antinous,
My own, my own good son.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One suit I have to make.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: To whom Fernando?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Lord Cassilane to you.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: This lady
Hath promised to be mine.

sp.speaker: Ann.
sp.l: Your blessing sir;
Brother your love.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: You cannot sir bestow her
On a more noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cas.
sp.l: Sayest thou so?
Antinous I confirm it. Here Fernando,
Live both as one; she is thine.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And herein sister,
I honour you for your wise settled love.
This is a day of triumph, all contentions
Are happily accorded: Candy's peace
Secured, and Venice vowed a worthy friend. Exeunt.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
